title: Book Mark - Blank Space for a Name

description.text:
Just a simple Book Mark/Page Marker. The top portion has a space blank for a Name. I made another version of this with a Name at the Top.   
The Name on my original version was Embossed. I removed it so you can customerize it.  
The Words Book Mark are holed all the way through that add a nice visual touch just in case you forgot what this was sitting in your book for!  
Note: The Thin .stl bookmark file is 1.5mm thick and the original .stl file is 3mm thick. Inventor source file also included so that you can make changes.

• Print.
  • Read a book (or atleast start to read a book)
  • Insert where appropriate.
  • Put your book down and go somewhere.
  • Come back and start reading EXACTLY where you left off.

the holes are designed for 5/8 wire loom if you use a zip tie on the inside and the outside it should keep the loom from pulling away from the case.

Updated the Left plate and re-positioned the Pi mounts. I think that's it for now...

print_settings.Notes:: Both of the breasts, the pubic area and the armpits need supports.

description.text:
The height of this figurine is about 122 mm. The photo is of a bit different variant - the person is about 15% taller.

The print was made with 4 shells and 15% infill using eSun PLA.
I overkilled it by using 4 shells and 15% infill but I'll try another one with 3 shells and 10% infill soon.

I'm totally aware that the size of the model is also an overkill but my slicer hasn't had a problem with it yet.

I am very interested to see how smooth result can anyone make since PLA is simple to print but hard to chemically smooth. Hope to see lots of "I made it" photos. :)

PS. I did not make this from scratch this is an edited 3D model so I really do not claim credit for it.

description.text:
OpenLock 5.0 Wall "A" Tudor, Wood, Cross Beam Styles
With this group, the start of the remix of Devon Jones OpenForge 2.0 Wall Construction Kit: Tudor Wall Backs. This wall will work with OpenLock 5.0 Tudor Wood Column O Post Pillar http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179339 to turn this "A" style wall into a "C" (left or right hand version) or using 2 Column "O", you can create a "D" wall piece. This allows fewer 3d prints to add to your collection. Just print 4 "A" walls and you can, at anytime, have one of 4 different wall types. One style across 4 types based upon a standard "A" type.

Took the OpenForge 5.0 Bool Tool and matched with my base tile. Added wood texture to the outside of the base, in case this was to be a second floor wall. Shrunk the wall to 9mm thick, and as the wall was thinner than the base added wood texture to the top of the base.

This is a concept that I had been working on, thinner Tudor walls with wood post end caps to allow proper fitting, like the mid-wall styles that Printable Scenery has designed with their Rampage System. As Printable Scenery came out with the 5.0 precursor design files, it fit into what I wanted to accomplish in a more elegant way. I still may offer a thinner inner wall version like what I had first envisioned.

The top "nubs", I am not sold on, and have modified to fit the OpenLock 5.0 standard AND my odd base size, so this wall will stack on itself, but not on the OpenLock 5.0 wall, but an OpenLock 5.0 wall can stack upon this wall, thus this is still a work in progress.
Have printed previously the Chevron Down version, as shown, found the first layer thickness kept the nubs from working correctly, but even if you do print with a wider base layer for adhesion, an easy fix is to take a drill bit and "carve" out the base for the pegs to work better.
Have not printed this version as of 03/21/17

title: e3d-V6 Exhaust Fan Shroud for MakerFarm Pegasus or Others

description.text: This is a simple little 30mm fan shroud for the e3d V6 hotend which has the fan pointing straight out the side which can negatively impact prints on that side of the print bed. My prints curled badly when using ABS and printing large flat things. I'm hoping this will help others experiencing the same issue!

comments.text: Wait, isn't the fan meant to be directed in the opposite direction? https://wiki.e3d-online.com/wiki/E3D-v6_Assembly#Fan_.26_Duct
comments.author: davevanos

comments.text:
I'm not sure what you mean. The stock clip-on fan shroud can spin around to direct the air from the fan any way that you want it to. But that air blowing out horizontally still causes large flat abs prints to warp unpredictability.
My shroud directs the air up and away from the hot print. It may not help all printers but it's has definitely helped mine!
comments.author: davevanos

comments.text: Well normally the fan is pushing air into the heatsink, so this would only work as an intake.  I'm not saying its wrong, maybe your setup allows for a push/pull fan configurations, so you'd add this to the pull fan?  I was just curious how to make this work on my setup as the darn heatsink fan definitely pushes air down onto the buildplate, so much that I don't ever end up using the layering fan.  But its a nightmare with abs.
comments.author: ngray1519

comments.text: Ah I get what you mean now.  Just reverse your fan wires and it should suck instead of blow.  I don't think it makes any noticeable difference in cooling of the hotend whether it's pushing or pulling air across the heat sink.
comments.author: davevanos

title: Enclosure for marlin PS_ON (Auto power off your printer)

description.text:
Description

This thing is an enclosure for a kit that works with marlin "PS_ON" feature.
This allows your printer to automatically powers off at the end of your prints.

Updates:

  • 2017.11.19 - AdedV3 of the box with additional holes on the power coord output. This allows you to power ON / OFF 2 separate equipment from this PS_ON module
  • 2017.03.22 - Fix hole position of the top plate
  • 2017.03.21 - Original Upload

Requirements

  • Marlin with PS_ON feature enabled
  • Any other firmware that supports M80 and M81 Gcode
  • Ramps 1.4 or any other boards that have the PS_ON pin available

BOM

  • 1 Momentary switch - LA38 type => http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/eletronic-components/281-push-button-switch-for-panel-mount-380vac-10a-1no-1nc.html
  • 1 meter 24 AWG dual black and red wire (about 1 meter) => http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/electronic/70-fil-double-24awg-rouge-et-noir-vendu-au-metre-lineaire.html
  • 2 x 1 pin Dupont connector and crimps
  • 1 Power supply cable (same as the one that goes to the Power supply of your printer)
  • A few cable ties for safety (2.5x100mm)
  • 8 x M3x8mm thermoplastic screws
  • 1 x PSU_OFF_BOX_V2_TOP.stl
  • 1 x PSU_OFF_BOX_V2_BOTTOM.stl

Kit and wiring documentation

All this is available here: http://3dmodularsystems.com/fr/upgrades/282-kit-pson-arret-automatique-pson-de-l-alimentation-de-votre-imprimante-3d-reprap.html

Enjoy 3D Printing

3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers

You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS

http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

description.text:
Another Easy to use Coin Opener - with a Handle. My buddy wanted one but wasn't going to keep it on a key ring.  
So I added a length of handle that gives it a bit of leverage for those pesky bottles.  
Just insert your Penny when the print is completed. Squeeze hard using pliers until it stops. The internal crevice for the penny makes it stick out the right length to open the bottle cap. ("channellock" type pliers seem to work the best.)  
Autodesk Inventor Source is attached.

• Print
  • Grab your bottled drink of choice in aniticipation of your printed product.
  • Insert Penny (Use pliers - "channellock" type seem to work the best.)
  • Open Bottled Drink
  • Marvel at your new easy open bottle opener.
  • Finally, enjoy your much deserved refreshing drink!

author: javigody

description.text:
This is a replacement for the rubber feet that attach a Line6 Pod (guitar effects processor) to an amp handle loop via the metal flange stand. I've been looking for these for years and still can't believe I never found them, since I feel like this is the sort of thing 3D printing is perfect for.

The originals were always pretty loose-fitting, and they got lost one by one over months of gigging. These actually stay firmly in the mounting holes in the flange/stand, so are a bit of an improvement. I printed using Ninjaflex at 100% on a Printrbot Simple. The front mounting holes are a little bigger than the back ones, so if doing it again I might try printing two at 103% and two at 100%.

I imagine these would work the same on the Bass Pod models. Let me know if these come in handy!

My first design of my own. Concept to start, basically I want to try and keep it clean on top. Made openings underneath for 6A ESC's, a 20x20 mounting holes for piko/femto, trying to route everything underneath. motors are spaced for 1103's.. going to print it tonight and see how it looks.

Any suggestions on a battery placement would be cool. I was somewhat considering using 4 "tiny whoop" type batteries and finding a spot for each on each arm... then wiring 2 in series and 2 in parallel for a 400ish mah 2s setup..

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fN3SsUBUFTp

This is a Refrigerator Door Shelf Bracket Mount thing.
It holds a bar from one edge of the inside door to the other for the shelf of a refrigerator.
Just print, flip in ReplcatorG and Print another for the other side. Then attach to fridge and the bar that keeps your bottles, dressing, ketchup, mustard or whatever else is in your fridge shelves - in your fridge shelves -and not flying off the shelf of the fridge when you open the door!

comments.text: Yes. Awesome. I was just thinking of making one of these. It would be awesome to make it customisable, so that it can fit to any fridge, and any bar shape.
comments.author: naught101

comments.text: Thanks naught101! Yes, a customizer version would be great. But I'm not sure how many factors could be customized for the mounting types needed to fit both the possible fridge door cutout and the possible shelf piece cutout and angle that might be needed. I'll have to play with the customizer ui some.
comments.author: naught101

remixed_from.title: OpenLOCK columns and side locking walls

description.text:
OpenLock 5.0 Full Window Circle Pane, Wall "A", "AB", "AB MIR" Tudor, Wood Styles
Added a circle style window pane as another window option.

With this group, the start of the remix of Devon Jones OpenForge 2.0 Wall Construction Kit: Tudor Wall Backs. This wall will work with OpenLock 5.0 Tudor Wood Column O Post Pillar http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179339 to turn this "A" style wall into a "C" (left or right hand version) or using 2 Column "O", you can create a "D" wall piece. This allows fewer 3d prints to add to your collection. Just print 4 "A" walls and you can, at anytime, have one of 4 different wall types. One style across 4 types based upon a standard "A" type.

Took the OpenForge 5.0 Bool Tool and matched with my base tile. Added wood texture to the outside of the base, in case this was to be a second floor wall. Shrunk the wall to 9mm thick, and as the wall was thinner than the base added wood texture to the top of the base.

This is a concept that I had been working on, thinner Tudor walls with wood post end caps to allow proper fitting, like the mid-wall styles that Printable Scenery has designed with their Rampage System. As Printable Scenery came out with the 5.0 precursor design files, it fit into what I wanted to accomplish in a more elegant way. I still may offer a thinner inner wall version like what I had first envisioned.

The top "nubs", I am not sold on, and have modified to fit the OpenLock 5.0 standard AND my odd base size, so this wall will stack on itself, but not on the OpenLock 5.0 wall, but an OpenLock 5.0 wall can stack upon this wall, thus this is still a work in progress.
Have printed previously the Chevron Down version, as shown, found the first layer thickness kept the nubs from working correctly, but even if you do print with a wider base layer for adhesion, an easy fix is to take a drill bit and "carve" out the base for the pegs to work better.

Have not printed this version as of 03/21/17, however the previous full pane version works well.

Kudos to Printablescenery

title: ROBO3D reprapdiscount LCD case custom fit

description.text:
DOES NOT FIT Bed Upgrade kit. It will fit my own upgrade kit and standard ROBO3d Bed on rails (old style)
Please complain to ROBO3D about the fact that R1 old and R1 new are both named R1, yet different. LCD Display from reprapdiscount modified to fit ROBO3D shell.
Requires platform lifters to add height, otherwise it will not fit.
V1.1 Modified bottom case for better fit and fixed bed rails bump into the case. Case is lowered (assuming you have platform lifters)
V1.2 Tweaked model for print without using support. Support will still require for SD slot gap.
V1.3 Bottom internal structure changed. Layer generation issues fixed (CURA users.)
v1.4 Changed angle for side mount to make it easier to print with less angle to deal with.
Platform pegs needed for height compensation.

title: LastAMP
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A "LAMP" for exhausting almost all of the remaining energy from a "dead" AA battery.

Sales figures from the leading battery manufacturers suggest that enough AA batteries were sold in 2016 to supply every American with 10 batteries, each.

Most common battery for US household use is the AA size "penlight" battery. An AA battery is sometimes referred to as HP7 in Britain.

The International Electrotechnical Commission designates the non-rechargeable AA battery as R6 & LR6. While the folks at the American National Standards Institute define an AA battery as size type 15 (e.g., 15D & 15A).

A "discharged" AA alkaline battery could have 0.8 - 1.33V of remaining "life" in it when you discard it. [from "Linden's Handbook of Batteries," Mc-Graw-Hill, 2001] In fact, the batteries removed from "dead" toothbrushes used during testing of this project, had 1.33V left in them.

This thing is derived from a circuit called a "joule thief" that was engineered by Big Clive at:
http://www.bigclive.com/joule.htm

This LAMP circuit uses a tilt switch (or, sensor) for powering the LED from the presumed, dead AA battery. The parts required for this project are:

BG Micro (bgmicro.com):
1x - 1/4 watt 5% resistors. Quantity of 200 - BG Part Number: RES1136 - $3.66
1x - Toroid cores are #6 mix(yellow) - BG Part Number: COL1058 - $1.10
1x - 2N3904 NPN TO-92 40V, 100 pcs - BG Part Number: TRN2N3904 - $6.00

Mouser (mouser.com):
1x - 611-RB-231X2 C&K Components Tilt Switches ROLLING BALL RB-231X2 $1.12 1,000/$0.694
OR, 611-RB-220-07AR C&K Components Tilt Switches ROLLING BALL RB-220-07A R $1.00 1,000/$0.615
OR, 612-TM1000Q E-Switch Tilt Switches 20mA 20VDCTM1000Q $1.54 1,050/$0.759

1x - 604-WP7113LSECKJ4 Kingbright 5MM LOW CURRENT ORANGE LED WP7113 $0.49 1,000/$0.176
OR, 859-LTL2R3FU3JSR Lite-On Amber 604nm Clear 5mm LTL2R3FU3JSR $0.20 500/$0.124
OR, 604-WP483EDT Kingbright Orange 625nm Diffused 7mcd WP483EDT $0.18 1,000/$0.081

1x - 12BH311P-GR Eagle Plastic Devices Holders 1 "AA" PC LEADS BLK $0.97 1,000/$0.53

And, two pieces (2x) of different colored thin 24 gauge (or, thinner) wire about 13-inches long, each. These wires are wrapped 10 times around and through the toroid. Upon completion, you will have four pieces of wire poking up and away from the toroid. It's easiest to wrap the wires together, two-at-a-time, around the toroid. See the wiring diagram and the photograph for a clear demonstration of this technique.

You will then join two wires from opposite sides of the toroid together. These two wires will be a different color (e.g., blue and yellow). This will result in a toroid that has three (3) connection points (i.e., a single blue, a single yellow, and a joined blue + yellow). It doesn't matter which color wire gets connected to the resistor and the transistor + LED. Just make sure that the dual joined connection is soldered to the red (+) connection from the AA battery holder.

Before you attempt to thread the lid onto the base, apply some standard household bar soap to the threads. If you get stuck, a wrench is supplied for helping to "coax" a stubborn lid off of the LAMP canister base.

Remember, reduce, reuse, and recycle.

remixed_from.author: Printablescenery
remixed_from.title: OpenLOCK columns and side locking walls

description.text:
OpenLock 5.0 Full Window Diamond Pane, Wall "A", Tudor, Wood Styles
Added a large diamond style and small diamond style multipane window as another window option.

With this group, the start of the remix of Devon Jones OpenForge 2.0 Wall Construction Kit: Tudor Wall Backs. This wall will work with OpenLock 5.0 Tudor Wood Column O Post Pillar http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179339 to turn this "A" style wall into a "C" (left or right hand version) or using 2 Column "O", you can create a "D" wall piece. This allows fewer 3d prints to add to your collection. Just print 4 "A" walls and you can, at anytime, have one of 4 different wall types. One style across 4 types based upon a standard "A" type.

Took the OpenForge 5.0 Bool Tool and matched with my base tile. Added wood texture to the outside of the base, in case this was to be a second floor wall. Shrunk the wall to 9mm thick, and as the wall was thinner than the base added wood texture to the top of the base.

This is a concept that I had been working on, thinner Tudor walls with wood post end caps to allow proper fitting, like the mid-wall styles that Printable Scenery has designed with their Rampage System. As Printable Scenery came out with the 5.0 precursor design files, it fit into what I wanted to accomplish in a more elegant way. I still may offer a thinner inner wall version like what I had first envisioned.

The top "nubs", I am not sold on, and have modified to fit the OpenLock 5.0 standard AND my odd base size, so this wall will stack on itself, but not on the OpenLock 5.0 wall, but an OpenLock 5.0 wall can stack upon this wall, thus this is still a work in progress.
Have printed previously the Chevron Down version, as shown, found the first layer thickness kept the nubs from working correctly, but even if you do print with a wider base layer for adhesion, an easy fix is to take a drill bit and "carve" out the base for the pegs to work better.

Have not printed this version as of 03/21/17, however the previous full pane version works well.

Kudos to Printablescenery
http://www.printablescenery.com/product-category/rampage-system/
Rampage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821631
OpenLock 4.0 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963
OpenLock 5.0 (pre-release columns)
OpenLOCK columns and side locking walls
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2098287
and DevonJones OpenForge
OpenForge 2.0 Wall Construction Kit: Tudor Wall Backs
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1641003

03/21/17 Added BA Window Walls

Here is a group of Marvin mash-ups.
These were all painted in Hatchbox 1.75mm silver PLA.
I used a sharpie to add the colors to the models.

Supports needed
Marvin Vader
Marvin Mickey

No Supports needed
Baby Marvin Groot
Marvin Yoda

More to come!!

title: X3 Z Brackets with Adjustable Tension

description.text:
I made a version of the Z brackets with adjustable tension. It will help with Z banding.

Install them as loose as you can (but without wobble) against the 2020. Without the lead screws attached the X axis arm should fall under it's weight.

V3 has alignment pieces that will line up to the 20/20 to make installation of the X axis easier.

comments.text:
Beltholder rutscht durch, wenn man mit einem Riemenspanner spannt.
Grund: Geringe bis keine Selbsthemmung in den Zähnen des Zahnriemen, da der Spalt am Beltholder zu groß ist.
Weiteres Problem ist, dort wo der Riemen umgelenkt wird, ist die Festigkeit bzw der Querschnitt zu gering und es bricht.
Lösung: Spalt enger machen und den schwächsten Querschnitt erhöhen. Es ist möglich, denn ich habe es an meinen Halter auch hinbekommen. ;-)

I was looking around my house for stuff I could etch with a laser. I saw a golf tee... hrmmm. Then it came to me. ETCH A GOLF TEE! If I can find it I'll post some pics.

I don't know what size the tee was, but it was a shorter one. For the long side of the tee, prop it up and make it secure in the laser. For the top, I stuck it through the hexagonal holes on the thingy that holds your thing (LOL), and secured it. I really don't remember what laser settings I used. I used a Epilog Helix laser. title: Customizable Square Fan to Pipe Adapter

description.text:
This was inspired by andygock's Parametric Square Fan to Pipe Adapter, (thanks Andy!) but is pretty much a total re-write to accommodate the square sections of most PC fans.
Version 2 has rounded corners as well as a nifty fan gasket creator.

The default "Version 1 object" is a 92mm fan (intake side) to 4" (10.1cm) flex pipe
The default "Version 2 object" is a 92mm fan (exhaust side) to 3" (7.86cm) flex pipe

Adjust the parameters in SCAD to make your own adapter!

title: Base for folded plastic lamp shade

description.text:
This is a base to make a standing lamp out of the Folded plastic lamp shade by hakalan (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:110736)

SCALE LAMP SHADE TO 150%

Things needed:

  • folded_vase.stl from here: (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:110736), scaled to 150%
  • GU10 socket like shown in the pictures. You can easily use an adapter for bulbs that fit other sockets like E14 or E27
  • zip tie as a strain relief for the cable. There is a little bridge at the bottom to attach the cable to. Drill a hole for the cable just above the bridge.
  • you need an external switch (on the calbe or somewhere else).

Only use low power bulbs like LED bulbs. Don't use anything that generates heat or you risk a fire.

description.text:
The Dyson V8 only allows for 2 accessories to be mounted to the wall mount. This adaptor allows for 4 accessories to be mounted (ie all that come with the Animal version).

There's two versions in the files: the normal version, and a version with the arm at 20 degrees. The Mini Motorised Head requires the 20 degree version otherwise it will rest on the wall. The close up photo shows the 20 degree version on the left. The other photo shows two standard versions.

The files provided are for the right side only. When slicing simply mirror them to create the left side. The alignment pin is not all that useful and can be ignored. Just glue and align the bottom piece manually.

27/01/18 - This design also works for the Dyson V7.

Kodama Trinus

Need some token storage? See my "Conquest Token Storage" project!

Update: March 31, 2017

Added tabbed versions of the large lid. Some of the taller card card trays had a tendency to flex, and the flat lid was not working very well. I've added both a 4-tab and an 8-tab version. These provide some structure by preventing the tray from flexing outwards.

Update: March 29, 2017

Added a card divider you can use to separate your cards by their armies in the larger card trays.

Update: March 28, 2017

Removed the expansion specific tray; too many expansions! Added a selection of X cards
trays instead. Renamed the Army tray to reflect that it is for the Core Armies, so only holds 30 cards. For expanded 50+ card decks, use the 60 (or more) card trays, if you want.

Card Trays (Core Set)

These interlocking card trays are a customized version of these excellent interlocking card trays, designed for the Core "Warhammer 40,000 Conquest" card game.

You will need to print the following for a complete set:

  • Conquest_Minion_Deck.stl x4 - Holds 10 cards
  • Conquest_Army_Deck.stl x7 - Holds 30 cards
  • Conquest_Misc_Cards.stl x1 (these contain the player reference cards, the planet cards, neutral cards, etc) - Holds 24 cards
  • Conquest_Lid_Large.stl x1
  • Conquest_Lid_Small.stl x4

If you have cards in addition to the base set, you can print the appropriate combination of X cards trays to hold them. You can also print the card divider if you want to organize your cards by individual armies.

Sizes

Sizes (Height x Width x Depth) in mm used in the customizer.

  • Large: 88.5 x 62.4 x 0.28
  • Small: 63 x 41 x 0.3

print_settings.Notes:: I printed mine with a raft because my bed was a little warped. It doesn't require a raft, or supports. Any print resolution that you typically print at will be fine with this. I printed mine with 10% infill, and it was a little bit bendy, but still worked. More infill might be recommended, but 10% isn't bad.

description.text:
I wanted an all-in-one case for my inkbird temperature controller for use with home brewing. I designed this to be able to have the controller visible from the front, and the outlet ports on top, using standard duplex outlets, not the single rectangular opening type. The power supply cable and the temp probe cable enter / exit the box from the back side.

M3 hardware secures the top to the bottom at the 4 corners, and your standard outlet hardware should work for the outlet.

This will fit on a 200x200 mm print area.

UPDATE: I didn't realize the bottom file was not the STL file. The STL has now been uploaded.

The STRIX StratoSurfer from ReadyMadeRC comes with a motor mount that requires a motor with a flat back. I wanted to use a Cobra C2213 in this plane, but it has a shaft that protrudes out the back. This mount can hold that motor and probably any others with a 3.17mm shaft that's less than 12mm long and uses a standard mounting hole pattern.

title: Suzuki VZR1800 aka M109R tachometer relocation case

description.text:
This is a 3d printable case for Suzuki Boulevard M109R / Intruder VZR1800 motorcycle tachometer, to relocate it into headlight cover.
Newer versions have this as standart, but mine is older and has the tachometer on the handlebar.
I did not want to ruin the original tachometer case, which would require cutting, so I designed my own. Printed it with PLA and put it on as it is for now, without any sanding/painting.
You will need a 1mm thick acrylic glass. Cut the back panel of the headlight cover to accomodate this case and seal it with some sealant to prevent moisture from getting into the case.
I used white sealant in the beginning because I had it laying around, but my next version will be sanded and sealed/painted fully in black.

title: Circumrelator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[Text en Català]

El Circumrelator, una màquina de pensar

Què és?

Una joguina creativa, basada en l’Ars combinatòria lul·liana, que ajuda els nens i nenes, nois i noies, a estimular i accelerar els processos creatius relacionats amb la composició de contes, poemes, o d’altres gèneres literaris.
Esdevé, també, una eina que serveix de guia a l’hora de cercar idees i d’obtenir material creatiu.

Per a què serveix?

Per viure la creació literària com una experiència positiva. Escriure literatura esdevé un joc d’associacions i d’atzar a partir del qual crear un text literari deixa de ser una activitat angoixant pels menys experts -- el buit de la pàgina en blanc, escriure com a imposició, escriure des de la distància emocional, etc. --, per convertir-se en un joc que beu del poder suggerent i evocador que cada paraula té en les experiències i vivències de cada persona. L’ús d’aquesta eina parteix d’una metodologia lúdica i creativa basada en el poder evocador de paraules, l’atzar i les associacions suggerents que l’Ars combinatòria proporciona.

A partir d’aquí, els nens i nenes obtindran un seguit d’expressions, frases o versos bonics i suggerents que hauran de polir i enllaçar per tal de donar forma a una composició literària i artística.

Més informació:
http://agora.xtec.cat/cesire/portada/el-circumrelator-una-maquina-de-pensar-i-crear/

[Text in English]

The Circumrelator, a thinking machine

What is it?

It's a creative toy, based on Ramon Llull (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramon_Llull) Ars combinatorial, which helps students encourage and accelerate creative processes related to the composition of stories, poems and other literary genres.
It also becomes a tool that serves as a guide when searching for ideas and creative material.

Why is it useful?

To face creative writing as a positive experience. Writing literature becomes a game of chance and associations from which to create a literary text ceases to be a stressful activity for beginners - the emptiness of the blank page, writing as a duty, writing from an emotional distance, etc. - to become a game, inspired by the evocative and suggestive power of words for each person. This tool is based on a creative methodology that uses the evocative power of words, random play and suggestive associations that the Ars combinatorial provides.

With this tool, students get a set of beautiful and evocative expressions, phrases or verses that they will improve and shape a literary and artistic composition.

[More information]

http://agora.xtec.cat/cesire/portada/el-circumrelator-una-maquina-de-pensar-i-crear/

Printer:

Sigma - BCN3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

[Text en Català]
Els nois i noies (12 a 16 anys) hauran de crear un text creatiu utilitzant un circumrelator (que hauran de dissenyar i, posteriorment, construir amb una impressora 3D) que els ajudarà a escriure textos literaris. Aquesta activitat fomenta l’escriptura, la creativitat i la interdisciplinarietat. Intervenen en l’activitat els àmbits de llengua, tecnologia i arts. [Text in English]
Students (age 12 to 16) will have to produce a creative text using a circumrelator (which they will have to design and then build using a 3D printer) that will help them write literary texts. This activity promotes writing, creativity and interdisciplinarity. The areas involved are language, technology and arts.

This is the Trautman Hook that was put in the public domain and can be found on http://openprosthetics.org/ This is not as much an object that I hope people will be printing, I sincerely hope to call out to those those with designs skill, prototyping capacity and vision to collaboratively create innovative, useful and affordable prosthetic 'systems'. I hope that you will not limit your ideas to just the rapid prototyped parts but use all of your making experience. I hope this will be the start of a discussion of what the RepRap/Makerbot/BfB/etc. (and commercial RP/AM) community can do for for those who are unfortunate. I'm confident that we can exchange valuable ideas! Most of us have spare motors, controller boards and various other electronic and mechanical parts, moreover they are similar so we could reproduce each others' solutions including non-RP parts! Some questions for discussion:
  • How do we make it fit perfectly? (e.g. 3D scanning a clay negative imprint, sparse structure against sweating, etc.)
  • What would the ultimate prosthetic 2.0 (sorry for the buzz words!) that you can make for a low budget (e.g. 300 euro's) look like, given the collective tools, personal networks and knowledge that we have?
  • Given that we have access to Arduino's (nano would be appropriate), encoders, servo's, accelerometers, gyro's, RFID chips (context aware prosthetics) and varous other tools.
  • Can we make prosthetics cool (an not necessarily creepy at the same time). LED's, smooth organic shapes. Not all of us want to look like the Borg.
  • Do we know amputees willing to try them and provide directions? (I do, for a lower arm amputee)
  • RP parts as light weight sparse structures e.g. ready for fibre layup (composites, etc.). I know it seems much more daunting and serious than the mouse trap challenge that did so well and was a lot of fun. I hope you don't feel like it has to be done right at once and just try out a few things. Please do have fun and try out crazy ideas!
  • How do we increase the contact surface to improve grip. Currently small contacts point will allow you to either crush or drop an object and hardly anything in between. Obviously, intricate structures with flexible parts can be made fairly easily with 3D printing.
    • I don't intend to just replicate a discussion here while the Open Prosthetics community has their own group. So please get involved in the discussions there if you're interested! The image with the foosball table is from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Army_prosthetic.jpg

description.text:
Provided are STL files for the 101Hero.
I also link the source SLDPRT files

I will eventually modify some parts to improve it. I will dub it the "201SuperHero"
Thanks to Xander Carey for the name.

Designed in SOLIDWORKS 2017 and same program used to export as STL (default export settings, IDK what they are)

Measured using 6 inch Mitutoyo Vernier Caliper (not digital)
+/- 1/128 inch

I did my utmost in making the names descriptive. My design method heavily relied on symmetry. Some parts were initially assumed symmetrical but actually weren't which made design completion hold up a lot.

I sourced some files from users on GrabCAD. I add their usernames into the filenames.

I also sourced files from McMasterCarr

Some files were not exactly right from those sources, and I modify them.

One little adventure was the limit switch. Nobody seemed to have modeled the exact one on our printer. So I found the datasheet and modeled it.

I did my very best to be as accurate and detailed as possible.

In the process I actually cut myself with my sharp edged caliper. It was also hot on that day. And that cut kinda made me tear up a little.

I literally put my blood, sweat, and tears into this thing. :)

SLDPRT Files
https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B1SSZ2gktfbKM25WbGZMb3dUZWM

STL Files

title: Raspberry Pi Camera (v2) mount for Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
This camera mount is a remix of things 1579789 and 1646474. The mount is designed to work with the Prusa i3 Mk2 printer and Raspberry Pi camera v2.

The remix uses the arm (with modifications to fit Mk2) and mounts from thing 1579789 and a redesign of the camera case from 1646474.

Hardware needed:
1x M3x40 hex head (ISO 4017) (attaches camera mount through swivel)
1x M3x10 (replaces M3x8 attaching to heatbed)
1x M4x10
4x M2x2 (mount pi camera into front of case - optional)
1x M3 nut (fits in fastener piece)
1xM4 nut (goes in swivel mount during printing)

I have the camera attached to a Pi mounted on the printer frame. I used the 6' Adafruit cable.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Parts all printed fine on Mk2 without supports.

Case prints fine at 0.3 resolution - I haven't tested other parts at 0.3.

You will need to pause printing of the swivel mount part way through to add the M4 nut. I did this at layer 23 at 0.2 resolution.

title: Folding Nintendo Switch Table-Top charging stand v3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update v3 (29.03.2017)
  • Add small nubs to keep the small hinge expanded and prevent it from collapsing by its own before inserting the Nintendo Switch (see comment). It's a snap fit. Make sure to adapt the tolerances for your filament to get the right amount of grip in the hinges. The part is designed with a 0.3mm gap between the moving parts. I printed the part without any issues on my Ultimaker 2+ with Innofil SILVER METALLIC PLA and it came out beautifully.

Print File: switch-stand-collapsed-v3.stl

Initial Release v2

Print it in one go. No screws, no glue needed.

Print File: switch-stand-collapsed-v2.stl - the other file (switch-stand-expanded-v2.stl) is just to show how it should look like in the expanded form.

Tired of not being able to recharge the Switch in table-top mode? Use this portable and foldable stand for the Nintendo Switch, which fits in every pocket and can be easily unfolded.
The Nintendo Switch can be charged while playing. It has a robust stand for it's small footprint and only 18 grams of weight. The switch is securely held using it's two bottom holes sliding over the supplied nubs.

Size collapsed: 99mm x 68mm x 8mm

You are not allowed to use this thing for commercial purposes. When you would like to sell prints, please contact me in advance so we can work out a solution.

Please make sure to reference to the source properly, when you are using this thing. Thank you.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

150 microns

Infill:

15%

Notes:

PLA works best, because of no brim. For ABS, PC or HIPS make sure to have a brim with at least 10 perimeters around the object with zero distance (1 layer thickness) because of the small footprint and the longish narrow parts which tend to shrink unevenly during the print.
I use a durable PEI coated build plate to print on. Some Gluestick or 3DLac will also help keeping the print stuck in place.

• Step 1: In case you used a brim, make sure to cut through the brim-surface to free the moveable parts. To make it easier, check the top side (the side having the pins) and go along the boundaries with a cutter or a scalpel.
  • Step 2: Carefully break the hinges free. Start from the outermost hinge and work yourself to the center.
Pull at the marked positions (1) upwards and push down the part with the small pillars next to it to loosen the first hinge. After that, continue with the second hinge (2) in the marked direction.

title: Dr Dabber Boost Base Stabilizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I use a Dr Dabber dabbing rig. Its a bit tipsy standing on its base and I have accidentally knocked it over several times just brushing it reaching around it. Once broke the glass. :(

I designed this coaster like thing to attach to the bottom to make it wider give it a bit more stability.

Its a tight friction fit. To install, I placed the magnetic base upside down on the floor, place the stabilizer on top of that and carfuly pressed it on with my heal. It snapped right on with a little pressure.

I included the open scad file so you can make it bigger or smalled. Edit the BaseDiameter to what ever you would like. The magnetic base is 40mm and the default for the stabilizer is 70mm.

If you need to change anything else, I would look at calibrating your printer first.

description.text:

This is my "PiMon" aka Pi Monitor. It has been designed to accommodate the Makibes 5" HDMI LCD Touchscreen.

The design provides a simple click together case to LCD (4 small screws will be required to secure the screen in place - or a glue gun).

The default setup is designed for HDMI use, however if access to the GPIO connector is required, access has been provided at the rear, where a 20 pin ribbon cable can be connected.

author: pamelafox

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7XwGa5iJV2Y

UPDATE : I took a 90 second exposure at a dark sky site with this adapter and got the most amazing results. Image has been attached, to show what this is capable of.

VER 2 has lowered holes for the top facing bolts, for those of you with big lenses.

Adapter plate to connect Orion EQ-1 equatorial tripod with a DSLR camera. Very steady - i've taken 4 minute exposures with it, with the optional EQ drive accessory.

Print a little on the hot side (I used 210 for PLA) and high infill (40% here) for strength. Bottom side of the plate has a round circle for tightening to your camera with a socket. Other two holes line up with the EQ-1 piece, and hardware store bolts latch it down. Use 1/4 x 20 bolts all around.

I also printed with 4 outside perimeter layers, instead of the normal 2. Make it as solid as you can for astro photography.

I needed a small C-clamp and I couldn't find any small enough at the hardware store.
Even printed with 25% fill it's quite rigid.

Required parts: 1/4 20 nut
1/4 20 bolt 3/4 to 1 inch long, allen head recommended Assembly: Slide in nut, screw bolt into hole.

title: 3D printer power supply hanging ENCLOSURE mounts

description.text:
Designed for my PSU for the enclosure im making. Designed to hang from the top, above the printer, or below the enclosure. Leaves a 1 inch gap for air flow for the top mounted fan. Print 4.

This particular PSU was from ebay, with many other PSUs having the same screw mounting location, that being 8.5mm from the bottom. I also have screws in this location on two other PSUs, so it seems somewhat universal. This PSU is the 12v, 30A / 360 watt out. I've also included the 123D file, so you can push and pull the lower surface, if the screws don't quite line up.

I used PLA at 210c, 25% infill.

description.text: use infill. 5 or 10% or the top will cave in. other than that no support should pop off the plate pretty easy.

This is a simple standoff for mounting a 60mm light ring on your Prusa i2 X carriage. If your carriage has the typical set of 3 mounting holes for the extruder, you can print 2 of these standoffs to secure the light ring to the carriage.

For best printing, turn on support in your slicer.  
Print two of these standoffs and press them into your X carriage. You may need to trim or sand the tips to ensure they fit. It is best if they fit tightly. A 60mm light ring will slip into place and stays put even during rapid movement.   
If the fit is tight you do not have to cement them in place however it is best to do so if you want to mount the light ring permanently.  
The default height is 20mm but you can change the height and regenerate a .stl file from the OpenSCAD file.   
Enjoy!

This thing is a bracket that holds up a piece of 14 mm eggcrate using suction cups from a spare MaxiJet powerhead.  The eggcrate platform can then be used to hold coral frags inside an aquarium until they have grown out or until you are ready to sell them at a local frag swap.

I have provided a plate with both one and two of these brackets.
  • Print out at least two of these brackets.
  • Grab two spare MaxiJet suction cups from your pile of reefkeeping equipment and push them into the holes.
  • Cut a section of 14 mm eggcrate into an appropriate length shelf. A 2" x 10" section is a good starting point.
  • Attach the brackets to both ends of the eggcrate.
  • Stick them to the inside of your aquarium wall.
  • Place coral frag plugs mounted with coral into the square holes.
    • NOTE: I included the SCAD file in case you need to adjust the size of the suction cup hole. I recommend any of the three coral frag plugs here on Thingiverse:
  • Shane's coral frag plug: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16982
  • Shane's two-piece frag plug with removable top: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17313
  • Joanne's Frag Plugs by engineglue: thingiverse.com/thing:16959
    • Print the brackets in either ABS or PLA. Print the frag plugs in PLA since they are more dense.

title: Magnetic Travel Chess
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
MAGNETS, MAGENTS, MAGENTS!!!!! Order them now, because you will need at least 104 to make this chessboard and pieces!

Designed in Sketchup, sliced with Slic3r, and printed on Prusa Mk2 (currently only single extruder until the 4 colour arrives :O). This is my first design, so here goes.....

  1. Magnets - Designed around 1/4" rare earth magnets as found here: http://www.leevalley.com/en/wood/page.aspx?p=32065&cat=1,42363,42348 I have ordered some cheaper ones from Asia, and may remix to fit in the future.

  2. Tiles - Start with a test print of the tiles to get your magnet dimensions correct. Remix the cylinder as required to fit, and note the dimensions as you will need them later. Once snug fit achieved, mass produce 32 of each color. I have cranked the Z-axis adjust on my printer high for bed adhesion, so I print them cavity up without support to make clean-up easier, and tops are still smooth. However your choice... Once printed insert magnets in cavity, and have fun stacking them up! At this point you also need to decide on your magnet orientation for the bases. Red dot up always up worked for me.

  3. Bases - Remix magnet cylinder as required and test print. Again you will need a magnet insertion point as determined by your slicer. At 0.20mm mine is at 3.10mm. Note in your slicer where the cavities get covered over, and manually pause the print to insert the magnets, or send your file here and have a filament change do the work: http://www.prusaprinters.org/color-print/ Print one to confirm process and test fit, then mass produce each side. (I have found the "hips" a little long for the mini-figs, so I use the slicer to "cut" off the top 1.2mm, but you can use a knife to do it manually) Practice the filament "change" / reinsertion on a base before you do the one on the board after a 9 hour print! Watch your magnet orientation.... Fit your favourite (or your children's least favourite that they will part with) mini-figs, and you have some players.

  4. Board - You will need two copies of the board. I like the detail of 0.20mm, however I have printed the hinge in another project at 0.35mm so it should work as well. There are four (4) magnet cavities in the board to hold it closed with the pieces inside. Again, remix the cylinders as required with same dimensions. At 0.20mm, my changes are at 24.30mm (~9 hours) and 29.20mm (~10 hours). I found starting the print late at night, and inserting magnets in the morning works well. NOTE THE ORIENTATION OF THE MAGNETS, AS TWO NEED TO BE UP AND TWO DOWN PER BOARD SIDE. I print face down with supports, which requires some cleaning. Go slow and use a knife...One hinge seems to print with support, and the other without, but they will both be fine. Clean-up the inside of the hinge with a small drill bit twirling it by HAND, and run a piece of filament through it a couple of times to clean it out. Ensure the board side under hinge is clean so that the board opens completely. Once clean snap the tiles on the top, and board is complete. If tiles do not fit properly, trim the squares on the board carefully with a knife. Fit is firm, but don't force it! You will discover how much you need to trim to get the fit right. Once both are printed and clean, insert a filament into the hinge and test closure. You may need to smooth the filament lines on the hinges to get a good operating board.

  5. Hats - While the bases are marked with the position and are of different heights, I have found it is still a little hard to distinguish the positions for young children. Replace the mini-fig hats with this cool collection, and it becomes a little easier. I normally print upside down to get the fit tight to the head with the exception of the king's crown.

FINAL NOTE: I would not recommend using Octopi with magnet insertion pieces. I lost a 9 hour print with 10 minutes left as I could not get the filament inserted quickly enough, and too many error messages were generated. Print from SD, and no chance of issues.

Happy printing!

title: Domino Cookie Cutter 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you like clarting about this is for you! Why not make your own edible set of dominoes.

This is a remix of my own earlier design "Domino Cookie Cutter".
I wasn't completely happy with the original design so I created this revised version which looks, feels and prints better.
Each stamp now comes in two parts which can be joined together using a "connecting_ring" and or glue. I would recommend using both.

Thing Files Include:

  • Number stamps 0-9. For convenience i have added Thing files of grouped objects for 28 & 55 piece sets as well as a file for each individual components .
  • Connecting Rings Each stam comes in two parts which are then joined together by a connecting rings. I would recommend also using glue for added secureity
  • Domino cutters in 4x & 5x sizes. It's optional which you choose to print. However when not in use the 4x version can hold the 7 stamps needed for the 28 piece set. The 5x version can hold all 10 stamps needed for the 55 piece set.
  • Containers for both 4x & 5x cutters, to hold all part together when not in use.
  • Diagram of dominoes in each set. It's probably worth printing this out although if you create the dominoes in a logical sequence it is pretty easy work out what you need.

Tips
The cutter is intended for use with dough 5mm thick. If you don't already own a tool for controlling dough thickness I would highly recommend downloading this customizable
Rolling Pin Spacer by Eckerput

Tips:
If the dough is sticking to the cutter use the 0 stamp to poke the dominoes out.

Enjoy :)

title: Mathematical Operations Dice
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a dice with some mathematical operations on each side. There is addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, exponents, and modulo. This can be used for deciding who goes first in a game or for math practice. Made with Fusion 360 and picture rendered with Blender.
Shown Also: Dice V1
CCSS

Introduction I originally created this for a project to decide who goes first. This can be useful for that sort of purpose. You can use this for activities or as practice. Not every side may be appropriate for every grade level grade level. You may have to explain what each side means (exponents = repeated multiplication, Modulo = remainder).

Activity A 1) Post 2 numbers on the board or a place where students can see. These numbers can be decided by a pseudorandom number generator, by dice throws, or by drawing cards / sticks. For older groups, you can choose to use negative numbers.
2) Have students roll the Operations Dice to find which operation they will be doing. Some operations may need explanation.
3) Have students calculate the answer. Choose a way to manage the numbers in the case that the number has more than a manageable number of decimal places (ex. truncation, rounding, bar notation, keep as is, fractions...). Activity B 1) Obtain a game that can be played in less than 10 minutes (ex. tic - tac - toe).
2) Have students roll 2 regular, 6 - sided dice and the Operations Dice.
3) Have students calculate based on the instructions for Activity A.
4) The person with the larger number goes first.

Activity A Operations Dice (1 per student)
Method of getting numbers Activity B 6 sided dice (2 per group)
Operations Dice (1 per group)
Short game (1 game per group)

A universal tool for all your kitchen cupboard handle hanging needs...

I had to replace the hardware on my kitchen cabinets, and I know from past experience that being off by even a millimeter is very visible. I decided to make a template this time around. It worked quite well, but while using it I thought of some more improvements. While I'm done with mine for a while, I thought I'd model them up, and post here for others to use.

With the download, you get:

  • A Main bracket with guide holes spaced at both 3" and 5" apart (fits most hardware). Deep guide holes help make sure the the drill does not go in on an angle

  • Adjustable guide which keeps main bracket square with side of cabinet door/drawer. Guide can be adjusted from around 1" to 7".

  • Holes in Main Bracket which accept 8-32 screws for locking the guide into place. If you don't have 8-32 screws, don't worry -- they come standard with most kitchen cabinet hardware!

  • Center markers on Main bracket which mark the centers of the 3" and 5" holes (for easy alignment)

  • Centering pins. Once one hole is drilled, pin can be inserted through the guide hole into drilled hole. This will keep the jig firmly in place. Also useful when going from single hole hardware to multi hole hardware. There's two holes on the main bracket to hold the pins when not in use. (The second pin is in case you break your first one. If you break both, you can use an 11/64ths drill bit instead)

  • Springs to hold jig in place. These can be mounted on the end of the guide, which hold the guide in place. There's two models -- one for 3/4" and one for 5/8" hardware. They can be mounted with 8-32 screws or with krazy glue.

A couple of quick hints:

Most kitchen hardware comes with 8-32 screws. You need an 11/64 drill bit to drill shanks for this (this jig is made assuming those sizes). Also most kitchen hardware have 3" or 5" center to center, but you should double check before printing this.

The pilot holes for the 8-32 screws used to lock the guide in place are a touch small (on purpose). You either need to tap those with an 8-32 tap or predrill with a 9/64 and then you can use a screw to self-thread.

The guide is quite long, so this has to be printed in PLA on a heated bed. Kapton tape is suggested. No supports required to print.

remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

description.text:
This project is a mounting system for phones and lightweight cameras.

FEATURES:

  • It is designed to be modular to provide flexible use. The system has potential to mount most phones and small cameras onto a wide range of objects. Using same parts printed for different purpose is the major approach.
  • The included phone clamp can grab phones very firmly. And it is suitable for phones from about 55mm wide to 80mm wide (iPhone 4 - iPhone 7 Plus and bigger). The clamp hook was angled 45 degrees so it won't be able to reach and accidentally press the buttons on the side of phone.
  • The modules can be used with GoPro compatible equipment. The bolts and nuts included in the design are standard M5. You can either print them or use metal ones for better stiffness.
  • With this modular system, I will be developing new add-ons to it. Feel free to watch this thing. Many of the objects designed for GoPro are already usable for this setup. I uploaded some STEP files for modular parts so everyone can also collaborate for better solutions.

ACHIEVED APPLICATIONS:

  • Phone/Camera/GoPro mount for Ultimaker 2 monitoring.
  • Phone/Camera/GoPro mount for Aluminum extrusion printers.
  • Desk clamp for phone/camera (get the bolt from original author page).
  • Stand for phone/camera.
  • Bike mount for phone (in remixes)
  • And much more applications in REMIX section

MAKING:

  • In order for the bolts to be strong enough to take pulling force, they cannot be printed vertically. Therefore the bolts are oriented horizontally, with the bottom teeth trimmed off, and with 30 degrees step shape (it is usually 45 if printed vertical). With such treatment the bolts are both strong and easy to print with support material even at 0.2mm layer height.
  • Print bolts and nuts at low outer wall speed (15mm/s) to increase accuracy. If the tolerence for bolts and nuts doesn't workout for you, try change XY compensation setting in slicer to get a larger tolerance. I've also attached the settings used to create them so you could make your own with slightly altered values.
  • Make sure you use metal bolts and nuts for mounting heavy items like camera.
  • It is highly recommended to print with complete support interface for the parts in this project. Support interface would give a flat bottom which result in a better mechanical performance.
  • The orientation of stl files are already thought through during my testing. Try printing at the current orientation unless you run into problems. It is not recommended to reorient the arms to save support material. The tabs will be easy to break if printed otherwise.
  • Mirror the arm one after another in order to have knobs on the same side.

NOTES:

  • It is not recommended to extend the arm too long. General filament is not strong enough to take that much lateral load at this size and the arm would be very wobbly. And the arms are optimized to stay still. If you wish to use this design as selfie stick or similar purpose, please be careful with the material strength and use at you own risk.

ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS:

  • The joints are inspired by GoPro design.
  • The foldable arm is inspired by "GoPro counter balance folding stick. by UltiArjan" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:433378).
  • Bolts and nuts are created with the awesome customizer "NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory by mike_mattala" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647).
  • The desk clamp is inspired by "G-Clamp fully printable by johann517" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1673030).
    Thank you all for your great work so that I could accomplish this project.

MOUNT BASES:

  • Tripod style base, good for small printers: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2767323
  • Bike mount: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2266715
  • CR10: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753828
  • Taz-6: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2750852
  • Flashforge Finder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2660921
  • Mount phone clamp on tripod: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2790283
  • Xbox One S controller: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2774549
  • Xbox 360 wired controller: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2553504
  • Xbox 360 wireless controller: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2794805
  • Sony PS3 controller: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2733267

OBJECT MOUNT:

  • Mini Fisheye lens: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2785451
  • Raspberry Pi night vision camera: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2657307
  • Raspberry Pi Zero W case and camera: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2504847
  • Elongated iPad Mini mount: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2482559

MULTIPLE AXIS JOINTS:

  • 3 DOF axis changer: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2358873
  • Ball joint: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2243294

OTHER KNOBS:

  • Long knob: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:163883
  • Short knob: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:537647

This is the list to indicate which function of the mount the parts belong to.
There is also a drawing made by willemjan for instruction: https://www.thingiverse.com/make:415832

MOUNTING BASE - the base to attach the mount to something:

  • Clip UM2
  • Clip 2020 profile
  • G-clamp
  • Flat stand

ARMS - the foldable arms and connectors:

  • Axis change connector
  • Arm v2 (anything)
  • M5.0 Nut
  • M5x25 D
  • M5 knob short

PHONE CLAMP:

  • Phone clamp down grab
  • Phone clamp up NO tab
  • Phone clamp up WITH tab
  • Phone clamp holder
  • M5x65 D
  • M5.0 Nut
  • M5 knob for phone
  • M5 knob short

CAMERA MOUNT:

  • Camera Mount
  • Camera Screw

• 22/03/17 - The phone clamp knob originally uploaded has issue of screw poping out of knob instead of knob pulling the clamp out. A new knob named "M5 knob for phone v2 tighter" with smaller hole is uploaded for the socket to firmly grab the bolt. "Phone clamp down nongrab" is an old backup version which the clamp doesn't pull out while unscrewing the knob.
  • 02/04/17 - More variation of arms. Added more tolerance to the arms.
  • 13/04/17 - A holder that grabs the phone clamp less tight. (Phone clamp holder v2)
  • 20/04/17 - After a period of use, the printed bolts or nuts start to give up, especially the nuts, not able to lock the arms in place. They are more like a temporary solution. I would buy metal bolts to replace them.
  • 24/04/17 - New version of the knob for phone clamp. More convenient to twist. Smaller diameter. (M5 knob for phone v3)
  • 26/04/17 - New version of the knob for the joints with smaller diameter. The long knob is no longer needed. (M5 knob short v3)
  • 09/05/17 - Longer M5x65 bolt for wide phones larger than 5.5 inch. (M5x65_D)
  • 18/05/17 - Mount for lightweight cameras! (Camera Mount & Camera Screw)
  • 18/05/17 - Moved the position of the nut in phone clamp, making it extend 10mm longer with M5x65 bolt. (Phone clamp down v3)
  • 18/05/17 - Slightly more tolerance to holes for bolt. Minor change.
  • 04/06/17 - New version of the knobs with better grip. (M5 knob short v4, M5 knob for phone v4)
  • 31/08/17 - New C clamp with the same width as the arms, not requiring support.
  • 14/02/18 - 4mm thicker phone clamp for phones with case. (Phone_clamp_down_4mm_thicker, Phone_clamp_up_4mm_thicker)

comments.text: Awesome thing! What would be your recommendation regarding infill / shells / material?
comments.author: mcamou

comments.text:
Standard 3 layer wall and 20% infill should be sufficient for most of the parts. I won't recommend "Line" type infill which change direction every layer for these sort of structural parts. "Grid" or "Rectangle" infill is stronger than "Line".
The small parts like bolts and nuts should be printed at 100% infill. PLA is good enough.

comments.text:
everything that is supposed to slide together or interlock needs to have a 0.2mm offset on either side to compensate for the 0.4mm orifice printing directly on the vector path. For example if you have 1 part that slides into another, you have 2 sides on each part that need 0.2mm offset to ensure proper fit. That's 4 sides that need the offset for the tolerance. That's 0.8mm total of material blocking the fit so it just won't slide together.
|<edge(0.2mm)center>|||||<center(0.2mm)edge>|
|<edge(0.2mm)center>|||||<center(0.2mm)edge>|
|<edge(0.2mm)center>|||||<center(0.2mm)edge>|
|<edge(0.2mm)center>|||||<center(0.2mm)edge>|
|<edge(0.2mm)center>|||||<center(0.2mm)edge>|
comments.author: cpa11225

comments.text:
0.8mm dimension difference is a very conservative number. Probably big enough for all printers and slicers to work.
I personally likes a smooth slide without any wobble so the current tolerance is set quite small after a few test prints. More resistance also helps the screw to hold the phone more securely under extreme situation such as bike mount.
Honestly if 0.8mm is needed for the slide to work, either the slicer is not optimised or the printer needs calibration.
I might make a version of the phone holder with more tolerance to work for more printers.
comments.author: cpa11225

comments.author: Duff8402

comments.text:
Thanks for the feedback.
The dimensions in model already have decent tolerance. The connectors work great while printed vertically.
While printed horizontally however, the three-tab end could be printed thicker than it should be and being too tight, and there are two reasons for this.
One is support z drop, which the layer is lower than it should be because it is printed on support with z distance gap.
The other reason is that layer thickness setting increases thickness of the model. Slicing at 0.2 layer height, the 3.2mm piece could get sliced as 17 layers due to its position.
I lay the arms horizontally because that's the only orientation making the tabs reliably strong. But it is harder for dimension precision. I'll try change spacing for horizontal tabs to work better.

title: Monoprice Maker Select Filament Eyelet Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have my filament spool mounted on my control box and wanted something really simple to guide the filament. This is my answer to the problem. The guide can be rotated when installed so that that the filament can be fed from the side or the front/back.

My time and PLA went into designing this thing. If this design blesses your life in some way, feel free to favor me with a tip as thanks. Gratuities are not required, but are definitely appreciated. You can tip me any amount that you would like here: https://www.paypal.me/brysonjack
Make sure to include a comment telling me which design it is. Thanks in advance.
